ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Intermediate Japanese grammar, vocab, and kanji.
Intermediate Japanese language skills (speaking, reading, writing, listening and kanji)
Good practicing speaking, listening, reading, and writing Japanese, using the Tobira 2 textbook through (including finishing) lesson 17.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: lots of time to practice speaking, forced to always use Japanese for practice, good pace, learned a lot of nuanced phrases to improve my speaking

Weaknesses: somewhat disorganized in that the teacher would post on canvas our homework later at night and did not release midterm grades so I didn't know how to improve
Nothing much, having language classes everyday hugely helped me develop my language skills.

The course design lacks organization, and the actual course often deviates from the syllabus. We haven't covered all the content as outlined in the syllabus. Additionally, there are instances where students receive assignment announcements and reflections later than expected.
Strengths is daily exposure to the language and teacher who encourages participation and high engagement in class. Could be improved with smaller class sizes, but that's dependent on course demand

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you are interested in Japanese culture and language
Yes, if you're interested in Japanese language and culture.

Yes - Namakmura-sensei's teaching style is not for everyone, but if you can overlook her initially intimidating aura, she's a teacher who utilizes methods that WORK and she does care deeply about her students. Don't be afraid to go to office hours. She is very helpful, is absolutely willing to practice more Japanese with you, and can explain to you the ideas behind her ways of teaching which are all very logically sound. She doesn't answer emails very consistently so just walk up to her after class, and she's very nice and willing to help then. Honestly, I am highly glad to be continuing level 4 Japanese with her next semester. While being cold-called in class can seem scary, and we didn't get very many grades until after term ended, I daresay my Japanese (especially speaking) has improved the most under her teaching, just from the sheer amount of participation expected and the high level of interaction she encourages among her students. Her expectations are also clearly laid out, and she even gives us kanji practice that directly help with the real tests. Just follow the rubrics and you won't go wrong. Give her a chance and see. I can see why she may not be for everyone, but I just want people to gain a perspective from a student who appreciates her teaching style the most out of all the Japanese teachers I've had
